Variance calculations between individual and colony level values

2024-07-09

Source: vignettes/F2_Variance_calculations.Rmd
F2_Variance_calculations.Rmd
library(package = "SIMplyBee")
#> Loading required package: AlphaSimR
#> Loading required package: R6
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'SIMplyBee'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     split
founderGenomes <- quickHaplo(nInd = 20, nChr = 16, segSites = 1000)
SP <- SimParamBee$new(founderGenomes)
nQtlPerChr <- 100
mean <- c(10, 10 / SP$nWorkers)
varA <- c(1, 1 / SP$nWorkers)
corA <- matrix(data = c( 1.0, -0.5, 
                        -0.5,  1.0), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)
SP$addTraitA(nQtlPerChr = nQtlPerChr, mean = mean, var = varA, corA = corA,
             name = c("queenTrait", "workersTrait"))
varE <- c(3, 3 / SP$nWorkers)
corE <- matrix(data = c(1.0, 0.3, 
                        0.3, 1.0), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)
SP$setVarE(varE = varE, corE = corE)
basePop <- createVirginQueens(founderGenomes, n = 20)
head(basePop@gv)
#>      queenTrait workersTrait
#> [1,]   9.308097  0.175604495
#> [2,]   9.229212  0.177669761
#> [3,]   7.838815  0.145594578
#> [4,]   9.031639  0.248186228
#> [5,]   9.868613  0.009881919
#> [6,]   9.378971  0.152665945
head(basePop@pheno)
#>      queenTrait workersTrait
#> [1,]   8.891549   0.09371756
#> [2,]  10.186057   0.32952109
#> [3,]   5.871084   0.28238299
#> [4,]   7.980709   0.07262322
#> [5,]  10.666579   0.11525851
#> [6,]  10.698284   0.06826125
drones <- createDrones(x = basePop[1:5], nInd = 3)
colony <- createColony(x = basePop[6])
colony <- cross(x = colony, drones = drones, checkCross = "warning")
colony <- addWorkers(x = colony, nInd = 50)
colony <- buildUp(colony)
apiary <- createMultiColony(basePop[7:20])
drones <- createDrones(basePop[1:5], nInd = 100)
droneGroups <- pullDroneGroupsFromDCA(drones, n = nColonies(apiary), nDrones = 15)
apiary <- cross(x = apiary, drones = droneGroups, checkCross = "warning")
apiary <- buildUp(apiary)
colonyGv <- calcColonyGv(apiary)
colonyPheno <- calcColonyPheno(apiary)

The idea of this work is:

  1. We want to do honey bee simulations with individual queens, drones, and workers

  2. To do the above, we require individual variances and covariances

  3. Literature reports only variances and covariances at the colony level

  4. The aim of this paper is to show how to use variances and covariances at the colony level to do simulations at the individual level.

Introduction WORK IN PROGRESS

This document develops theory for the variance of genetic and phenotypic values between colonies with the aim to understand how to fine tune a SIMplyBee simulation where we need variance components for queen and workers effects at an individual honeybee level. The challenge here is that in reality we do not observe such variances, but only on a colony level.

For example, in the vignette we assumed that phenotypic variance on the individual level is about 1/4 due to genetic variation and about 3/4 due to environmental variation, but looking at colony genetic and phenotypic variances the ratio was aobut 1/2!

TODO: What do we do about this? It feels like we need a full paper on all of this;) :(

Having multiple colonies and their values, we can now return to the “about” point mentioned at the start of this section, when we defined quantitative genetic parameters. Recall that our starting quantitative genetic parameters for the queen and workers effects were:

We will follow the example from Brascamp and Bijma (2019) they have:

σgq2=0.5\sigma_{g_q}^2=0.5 - this is their σAq2=0.5\sigma_{A_q}^2=0.5

σgw2=1.0\sigma_{g_w}^2=1.0 - this is their σAw2=1.0\sigma_{A_w}^2=1.0 among unrelated honeybees

σgw2=0.32\sigma_{g_w}^2=0.32 - this is their σA‾w2=0.32\sigma_{\bar{A}_w}^2=0.32 among averages of groups of honeybees?

σgq,gw=−0.35\sigma_{{g_q},{g_w}}=-0.35

σe2=2.0\sigma_e^2=2.0

h2=(abaseσg,w2+σg,w,g,qσg,q2)/σp,c2=???h^2=(a_base\sigma_{g,w}^2 + \sigma_{{g,w},{g,q}} \sigma_{g,q}^2)/\sigma_{p,c}^2=???

hw2=abaseσg,w2/σp,c2=0.13h_w^2=a_base\sigma_{g,w}^2/\sigma_{p,c}^2=0.13

hq2=σg,q2/σp,c2=0.20h_q^2=\sigma_{g,q}^2/\sigma_{p,c}^2=0.20

T2=(sigmag,w2+2σg,w,g,qσg,q2)/σp,c2=0.32T^2=(sigma_{g,w}^2 + 2\sigma_{{g,w},{g,q}} \sigma_{g,q}^2)/\sigma_{p,c}^2=0.32

Tw2=σg,w2/σp,c2=0.41T_w^2=\sigma_{g,w}^2/\sigma_{p,c}^2=0.41

Tq2=σg,q2/σp,c2=0.20T_q^2=\sigma_{g,q}^2/\sigma_{p,c}^2=0.20

rg=cor(gw,gq)=−0.50r_g = cor(g_w, g_q) = -0.50

TODO: equation 3 in Brascamp and Bijma (2019) is highly relevant to our work here - that equation shows connection between the variance of the sum (or average) of worker genetic values for worker effect AND variance of worker genetic values for worker effect - THIS IS WHAT WE WORK WITH HERE SO WHAT IS NOVEL IN OUR WORK? I think its about providing a tool and demonstrate it clearly. Also, they work with average, while we work with the sum?

TODO: show sensitivity to the number of workers - the larger the number of workers, the smaller the variance between workers

# Trait means
mean
#> [1] 10.0  0.1

# Trait genetic variation - on a per honeybee level
varA
#> [1] 1.00 0.01
corA
#>      [,1] [,2]
#> [1,]  1.0 -0.5
#> [2,] -0.5  1.0
(covA <- corA * outer(X = sqrt(varA), Y = sqrt(varA), FUN = "*"))
#>       [,1]  [,2]
#> [1,]  1.00 -0.05
#> [2,] -0.05  0.01

# Trait environmental variation - on a per honeybee level
varE
#> [1] 3.00 0.03
corE
#>      [,1] [,2]
#> [1,]  1.0  0.3
#> [2,]  0.3  1.0
(covE <- corE * outer(X = sqrt(varE), Y = sqrt(varE), FUN = "*"))
#>      [,1] [,2]
#> [1,] 3.00 0.09
#> [2,] 0.09 0.03

# Trait phenotypic variation - on a per honeybee level
(covP <- covA + covE)
#>      [,1] [,2]
#> [1,] 4.00 0.04
#> [2,] 0.04 0.04
(corP <- cov2cor(covP))
#>      [,1] [,2]
#> [1,]  1.0  0.1
#> [2,]  0.1  1.0
(varP <- diag(covP))
#> [1] 4.00 0.04

# Expected phenotypic variation - on a per colony level
# TODO: there is in fact more stuff happening here - see below! 
nW <- SP$nWorkers # TODO: this is not correct - we have queen-workers pairs and workers-workers (see below!)
# Var(z)=Var(x+y)=Var(x)+Var(sum(y))=Var(x)+Var(y_1)+Var(y_2)+...
# this is all wrong likely ...

k <- 1 # just adding this so vignette can run, but I don't know what this k should be

covA[1, 1] + nW * covA[2, 2] + 2 * k * covA[1, 2] # variance can not be negative!
#> [1] 1.9
covP[1, 1] + nW * covP[2, 2] + 2 * k * covP[1, 2]
#> [1] 8.08

# Observed variation - on a per colony level
var(colonyGv)
#>          [,1]
#> [1,] 22.48367
var(colonyPheno)
#>         [,1]
#> [1,] 20.8878
var(colonyGv) / var(colonyPheno)
#>          [,1]
#> [1,] 1.076402

Hmm, we have much higher genetic and phenotypic variances in simulation than based simply looking at queen and n*workers variances, as well as much higher ratio between the two than the initial value of ~1/4! Why? Let’s see. For genetic value of a colony gcg_c we add up the queen’s genetic value for the queen effect gq,qg_{q,q} and workers’ genetic values for the workers effect Σi=1nw(gi,w)\Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w}):

gc=gq,q+Σi=1nw(gi,w).g_c = g_{q,q} + \Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w}).

Expectation of colony genetic value is then:

E(gc)=E(gq,q+Σi=1nw(gi,w))E(g_c) = E(g_{q,q} + \Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w}))

E(gc)=E(gq,q)+E(Σi=1nw(gi,w))E(g_c) = E(g_{q,q}) + E(\Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w}))

E(gc)=μgq+nwE(gw,w)E(g_c) = \mu_{g_{q}} + n_w E(g_{w,w})

E(gc)=μgq+nwμgwE(g_c) = \mu_{g_{q}} + n_w \mu_{g_{w}}

we are assuming here that nwn_w is a fixed value, but if it is a random variable then we would have

E(gc)=μgq+E(nw)E(gw,w)E(g_c) = \mu_{g_{q}} + E(n_w) E(g_{w,w}) using https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distribution_of_the_product_of_two_random_variables

E(gc)=μgq+λnwμgwE(g_c) = \mu_{g_{q}} + \lambda_{n_w} \mu_{g_{w}}

where λnw\lambda_{n_w} is average number of workers. So, in our case this turns out the same as above. So in our case we have:

nW <- SP$nWorkers
mean[1] + nW * mean[2]
#> [1] 20
mean(colonyGv)
#> [1] 21.43936
mean(colonyPheno)
#> [1] 21.43315

Variance of colony genetic value is then:

Var(gc)=Var(gq,q+Σi=1nw(gi,w))Var(g_c) = Var(g_{q,q} + \Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w}))

Var(gc)=Var(gq,q)+Var(Σi=1nw(gi,w))+2Cov(gq,q,Σi=1nw(gi,w))Var(g_c) = Var(g_{q,q}) + Var(\Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w})) + 2Cov(g_{q,q}, \Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w}))

Var(gc)=σgq2+Var(Σi=1nw(gi,w))+2Cov(gq,q,Σi=1nw(gi,w))Var(g_c) = \sigma^2_{g_{q}} + Var(\Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w})) + 2Cov(g_{q,q}, \Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w}))

So, we have three parts:

  1. the variance of the queen effect in queens σgq2\sigma^2_{g_{q}},

  2. variance of a sum of workers effect in workers Var(Σi=1nw(gi,w))Var(\Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w})), and

  3. covariance between the two 2Cov(gq,q,Σi=1nw(gi,w))2Cov(g_{q,q}, \Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w})).

A) Variance of the queen effect in queens σgq2\sigma^2_{g_{q}} - in our case this is: 

varA[1]
#> [1] 1
var(getQueenGv(apiary, collapse = TRUE)[, "queenTrait"])
#> [1] 0.8365685
# ... note that R's var() divides by n-1, which matters with small n
sum((getQueenGv(apiary, collapse = TRUE)[, "queenTrait"] - mean[1])^2) / nColonies(apiary)
#> [1] 0.9225551

Anyway, quite close!

B) Variance of a sum of workers effect in workers Var(Σi=1nw(gi,w))Var(\Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w}))

Given that this is a sum, we need to look at:

B1) variance of each of worker genetic values Var(gi,w)Var(g_{i,w}) and

B2) covariance between each pair of the values Cov(gi,w,gj,w)Cov(g_{i,w}, g_{j,w}).

This means, that family structure will start to matter because it induces covariance between family members (workers). The simplest case is when all workers come from the same father. Then we have:

g1,w=12gq,w+gf,w+r1,wg_{1,w} = \frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f,w} + r_{1,w}

g2,w=12gq,w+gf,w+r2,wg_{2,w} = \frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f,w} + r_{2,w}

…

gnw,w=12gq,w+gf,w+rnw,wg_{n_w,w} = \frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f,w} + r_{n_w,w}

B1) variance of each of worker genetic values Var(gi,w)Var(g_{i,w})

As stated initially, we have Var(gi,w)=σgw2Var(g_{i,w}) = \sigma^2_{g_{w}} and we have nwn_w such terms, nwσgw2n_w \sigma^2_{g_{w}}. In our case this would be:

nW * varA[2]
#> [1] 1
g <- calcColonyGv(apiary, mapCasteToColonyGv, queenTrait = NULL, workersTrait = "workersTrait")
var(g)
#>              workersTrait
#> workersTrait     29.36575
# ... note that R's var() divides by n-1, which matters with small n
sum((g - nW * mean[2])^2) / nColonies(apiary)
#> [1] 28.3867

So, a huge discrepancy between the variance of a sum of genetic values for the workers effect nW * varA[2] (assuming independence) and a realised sum of genetic values for the workers effect. As we have seen above, this is due to family structure and associated B2) covariance between each pair of the values Cov(gi,w,gj,w)Cov(g_{i,w}, g_{j,w}).

B2) covariance between each pair of the values Cov(gi,w,gj,w)Cov(g_{i,w}, g_{j,w})

Clearly, these covariances matter a lot - there is lots of worker pairs in a colony! How do these covariances look like?

Cov(g1,w,g2,w)=Cov(12gq,w+gf,w,12gq,w+gf,w)Cov(g_{1,w}, g_{2,w}) = Cov(\frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f,w}, \frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f,w})

Cov(g1,w,g2,w)=Var(12gq,w)+Var(gf,w)Cov(g_{1,w}, g_{2,w}) = Var(\frac{1}{2}g_{q,w}) + Var(g_{f,w})

assuming that mother and father are not related; further genetic variance between drones is in fact half the genetic variance between queens because they are haploid, so we get:

Cov(g1,w,g2,w)=14σgw2+14σgw2Cov(g_{1,w}, g_{2,w}) = \frac{1}{4}\sigma^2_{g_w} + \frac{1}{4}\sigma^2_{g_w}

Cov(g1,w,g2,w)=12σgw2Cov(g_{1,w}, g_{2,w}) = \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_{g_w}.

Every pair of super-sister workers adds 12σgw2\frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_{g_w} to B - note that pair A-B adds this value, but so does the pair B-A, hence total is 212σgw2=σgw22\frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_{g_w} = \sigma^2_{g_w}. With nwn_w workers we get nwnwn_w n_w pairs (including with itself) or nwnw−nwn_w n_w - n_w pairs between different workers. The total covariance contribution is then (nwnw−nw)12σgw2(n_w n_w - n_w)\frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_{g_w}). In our case this would be:

(varSumWorkers <- nW * varA[2]) # B1
#> [1] 1
(covSumWorkers <- (nW * nW - nW) * 1/2 * varA[2]) # B2
#> [1] 49.5
varSumWorkers + covSumWorkers # B
#> [1] 50.5

g <- calcColonyGv(apiary, mapCasteToColonyGv, queenTrait = NULL, workersTrait = "workersTrait")
var(g) # B
#>              workersTrait
#> workersTrait     29.36575
# ... note that R's var() divides by n-1, which matters with small n
sum((g - nW * mean[2])^2) / nColonies(apiary) # B
#> [1] 28.3867

If we would only have super-sisters we would have ~1 for B1, ~49.5 for B2, and ~50.5 for B, but with a mix of half-sisters and super-sisters we would have a lower value, which is what we see above, ~26.8 for B.

TODO: Define the setting above in intro or start of M&M - We also can have full-sisters, where the mother is obviously the same, but the fathers are different, yet they come from the same mother, which is equivalent to a full-sibs case in diploid species. We will assume in this work that we have unrelated queens and unrelated drones (=base pop) - our aim is to set variances in such a base population - to get the scale or the variances right. In simulation of our base population we generated drones from virgin queens, which means that our drones can in fact be brothers, so our realised variances might be a bit off compared to this theory. But this is fine, we are mostly trying to get the order of variances correct.

So, now we need to work out B2 with a mix of half-sisters and super-sisters :( Sister workers are related only due to having the same mother, assuming that drones the queen mated with are unrelated:

g1,w=12gq,w+gf1,w+r1,wg_{1,w} = \frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f1,w} + r_{1,w}

g2,w=12gq,w+gf2,w+r2,wg_{2,w} = \frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f2,w} + r_{2,w}

Cov(g1,w,g2,w)=Cov(12gq,w+gf1,w,12gq,w+gf2,w)Cov(g_{1,w}, g_{2,w}) = Cov(\frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f1,w}, \frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f2,w})

Cov(g1,w,g2,w)=Var(12gq,w)Cov(g_{1,w}, g_{2,w}) = Var(\frac{1}{2}g_{q,w})

Cov(g1,w,g2,w)=14Var(gq,w)Cov(g_{1,w}, g_{2,w}) = \frac{1}{4}Var(g_{q,w})

Hence every pair of half-sister workers adds 14σgw2\frac{1}{4}\sigma^2_{g_w} to B (note, this is 214σgw22\frac{1}{4}\sigma^2_{g_w} for A-B and B-A pairs!). With nwn_w workers and nfn_f fathers we have nwnf\frac{n_w}{n_f} workers per father. Further, we have nfn_f groups of super-sisters and nfnf−nfn_f n_f - n_f pairs of sister groups. Assuming that half-sister groups are the same size, we have nfnwnfnwnf=nwnwnf=nw2nfn_f \frac{n_w}{n_f} \frac{n_w}{n_f} = n_w \frac{n_w}{n_f} = \frac{n^2_w}{n_f} pairs of super-sisters and (nfnf−nf)nwnfnwnf(n_f n_f - n_f) \frac{n_w}{n_f} \frac{n_w}{n_f} - this is nf(nf−1)nwnfnwnf=(nf−1)nwnwnf=(nf−1)nw2nfn_f (n_f - 1) \frac{n_w}{n_f} \frac{n_w}{n_f} = (n_f - 1) n_w \frac{n_w}{n_f} = \frac{ (n_f - 1) n^2_w}{n_f}. Is this correct?

(nF <- nFathers(colony))
#> [1] 15
nW * nW
#> [1] 10000
(a <- nW * nW / nF)
#> [1] 666.6667
(b <- (nF - 1) * nW * nW / nF)
#> [1] 9333.333
a+b 
#> [1] 10000

Looks like!

So, super-sister pairs add nw2nf12σgw2\frac{n^2_w}{n_f} \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_{g_w} and half-sister pairs add (nf−1)nw2nf14σgw2\frac{ (n_f - 1) n^2_w}{n_f} \frac{1}{4}\sigma^2_{g_w}. Let’s test this:

(varSumWorkers <- nW * varA[2]) # B1
#> [1] 1
(covSumWorkersSuperSisters <- (nW * nW / nF) * 0.50 * varA[2]) # B2 in super-sisters
#> [1] 3.333333
(covSumWorkersHalfSisters <- ((nF - 1) * nW * nW / nF) * 0.25 * varA[2]) # B2 in half-sisters
#> [1] 23.33333
varSumWorkers + covSumWorkersSuperSisters + covSumWorkersHalfSisters # B
#> [1] 27.66667

g <- calcColonyGv(apiary, mapCasteToColonyGv, queenTrait = NULL, workersTrait = "workersTrait")
var(g) # B
#>              workersTrait
#> workersTrait     29.36575
# ... note that R's var() divides by n-1, which matters with small n
sum((g - SP$nWorkers * mean[2])^2) / nColonies(apiary) # B
#> [1] 28.3867

Cool - very close!!! There can be some difference because the formulae above assume that we have fixed sizes of half-sister and super-sister groups. Also, there can be full-sisters in there as well!!!

TODO: We could also add full-sisters: To do this, we would have to assume how many brother drones we use to figure out the grups

TODO: What if nwn_w is a random variable? Following https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distribution_of_the_product_of_two_random_variables we would use:

Var(XY)=(Var(X)+E(X)2)(Var(Y)+E(Y)2)−E(X)2E(Y)2Var(XY) = (Var(X) + E(X)^2) (Var(Y) + E(Y)^2) - E(X)^2 E(Y)^2

but this is for two variables, while I have nwn_w genetic values, so this reference result is not that useful in our case! Well, if nwn_w varies between colonies, this must boost variance of colony-level genetic values significantly, because kind of start calculating variance between apples (small colonies) and oranges (large colonies).

C) Covariance between the two 2Cov(gq,q,Σi−1nw(gi,w))2Cov(g_{q,q}, \Sigma_{i-1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w})).

Let’s repeat:

g1,w=12gq,w+gf1,w+r1,wg_{1,w} = \frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f1,w} + r_{1,w}

g2,w=12gq,w+gf2,w+r2,wg_{2,w} = \frac{1}{2}g_{q,w} + g_{f2,w} + r_{2,w} …

The essential bit here is:

Cov(gq,q,gi,w)=Cov(gq,q,12gq,w)Cov(g_{q,q}, g_{i,w}) = Cov(g_{q,q}, \frac{1}{2} g_{q,w})

assuming that the queen and fathers are unrelated. Then:

Cov(gq,q,gi,w)=Cov(gq,12gw)Cov(g_{q,q}, g_{i,w}) = Cov(g_{q}, \frac{1}{2} g_{w})

Cov(gq,q,gi,w)=12Cov(gq,gw)Cov(g_{q,q}, g_{i,w}) = \frac{1}{2} Cov(g_{q}, g_{w})

Cov(gq,q,gi,w)=12σgq,gwCov(g_{q,q}, g_{i,w}) = \frac{1}{2} \sigma_{g_{q},g_{w}}

So:

2Cov(gq,q,Σi=1nw(gi,w))=2Cov(gq,q,nw12gq,w)2Cov(g_{q,q}, \Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w})) = 2Cov(g_{q,q}, n_w \frac{1}{2} g_{q,w})

2Cov(gq,q,Σi=1nw(gi,w))=2nw12Cov(gq,q,gq,w)2Cov(g_{q,q}, \Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w})) = 2 n_w \frac{1}{2}Cov(g_{q,q}, g_{q,w})

2Cov(gq,q,Σi=1nw(gi,w))=nwσgq,gw2Cov(g_{q,q}, \Sigma_{i=1}^{n_w}(g_{i,w})) = n_w \sigma_{g_{q},g_{w}}

(varQueen <- varA[1]) # A
#> [1] 1

(varSumWorkers <- nW * varA[2]) # B1
#> [1] 1
(covSumWorkersSuperSisters <- (nW * nW / nF) * 0.50 * varA[2]) # B2 in super-sisters
#> [1] 3.333333
(covSumWorkersHalfSisters <- ((nF - 1) * nW * nW / nF) * 0.25 * varA[2]) # B2 in half-sisters
#> [1] 23.33333
(varSumWorkers <- varSumWorkers + covSumWorkersSuperSisters + covSumWorkersHalfSisters) # B
#> [1] 27.66667

(covQueenSumWorkers <- nW * covA[1, 2]) # C
#> [1] -5

varQueen + varSumWorkers + covQueenSumWorkers
#> [1] 23.66667

g <- colonyGv
var(g)
#>          [,1]
#> [1,] 22.48367
sum((g - 20)^2) / nColonies(apiary)
#> [1] 22.94944


(varQueen <- varP[1]) # A
#> [1] 4

(varSumWorkers <- nW * varP[2]) # B1
#> [1] 4
(covSumWorkersSuperSisters <- (nW * nW / nF) * 0.50 * varA[2]) # B2 in super-sisters - only genetic cov here, I think TODO!?
#> [1] 3.333333
(covSumWorkersSisters <- ((nF - 1) * nW * nW / nF) * 0.25 * varA[2]) # B2 in sisters - only genetic cov here, I think TODO!?
#> [1] 23.33333
(varSumWorkers <- varSumWorkers + covSumWorkersSuperSisters + covSumWorkersSisters) # B
#> [1] 30.66667

(covQueenSumWorkers <- nW * covP[1, 2]) # C - pheno or genetic only here - TODO!?
#> [1] 4

varQueen + varSumWorkers + covQueenSumWorkers
#> [1] 38.66667

p <- colonyPheno
var(p)
#>         [,1]
#> [1,] 20.8878
sum((p - 20)^2) / nColonies(apiary)
#> [1] 21.44974

Bingo for genetic variance and very close for phenotypic too, but we need to check some part above!

What now?

Alright, what can we now do with this? We now have a system of expected genetic and phenotypic variances for colony values as a function of number of workers, fathers, and genetic and phenotypic covariances between the queen and worker effects. So, it should be possible, in principle, to solve for what kind of covariance values for the queen and workers effects should we use, to get the desired colony genetic and phenotypic variances!

TODO: develop such estimating equations!

So, we have genetic part:

Ag=σgq2A_g = \sigma^2_{g_q}

B1g=nwσgw2B1_g = n_w \sigma^2_{g_w}

B2g=nw2nf12σgw2B2_g = \frac{n^2_w}{n_f} \frac{1}{2} \sigma^2_{g_w}

B3g=(nf−1)nw2nf14σgw2B3_g = \frac{(n_f - 1) n^2_w}{n_f} \frac{1}{4} \sigma^2_{g_w}

Cg=nwσgq,gw2C_g = n_w \sigma^2_{{g_q},{g_w}}

here are 3 unknowns: σgq2\sigma^2_{g_q}, σgw2\sigma^2_{g_w}, and σgq,gw2\sigma^2_{{g_q},{g_w}}

we can add phenotypic part:

Ap=σpq2A_p = \sigma^2_{p_q}

B1p=nwσpw2B1_p = n_w \sigma^2_{p_w}

B2p=nw2nf12σgw2B2_p = \frac{n^2_w}{n_f} \frac{1}{2} \sigma^2_{g_w} TODO: check if its only genetic

B3p=(nf−1)nw2nf14σgw2B3_p = \frac{(n_f - 1) n^2_w}{n_f} \frac{1}{4} \sigma^2_{g_w} TODO: check if its only genetic

Cp=nwσpq,pw2C_p = n_w \sigma^2_{{p_q},{p_w}}

here are additional 3 unknowns: σpq2\sigma^2_{p_q}, σpw2\sigma^2_{p_w}, and σpq,pw2\sigma^2_{{p_q},{p_w}}

while we could provide as guidance 2, maybe 3, inputs: σgc2\sigma^2_{g_c}, σpc2\sigma^2_{p_c}, and σgc2σpc2\frac{\sigma^2_{g_c}}{\sigma^2_{p_c}}.

TODO: are there any additional inputs that we could get from literature? How do we connect all this with variance estimates for the queen and the workers effect in the honeybee genetics and breeding literature? I think that those estimates are essentially this: σgc2=σgc,q2+σgc,w2+2σgc,q,gc,w\sigma^2_{g_c} = \sigma^2_{g_{c,q}} + \sigma^2_{g_{c,w}} + 2\sigma_{g_{c,q},g_{c,w}} where σgc,q2\sigma^2_{g_{c,q}} is the queen part of σgc2\sigma^2_{g_c}, but not necessarily the same as σgw2\sigma^2_{g_w}, or is it? Maybe that is the same, and σgc,w2\sigma^2_{g_{c,w}} is a counterpart to nwσgw2+nw2nf12σgw2,(nf−1)nw2nf14σgw2n_w \sigma^2_{g_w} + \frac{n^2_w}{n_f} \frac{1}{2} \sigma^2_{g_w}, \frac{(n_f - 1) n^2_w}{n_f} \frac{1}{4} \sigma^2_{g_w} (TODO: should we add full-sisters?), while σgc,q,gc,w\sigma_{g_{c,q},g_{c,w}} is a counterpart to nwσgq,gwn_w \sigma_{{g_q},{g_w}}. If this is so, then it fells that we should have 3 more inputs for genetic part, so 4 inputs to estimate 3 unknowns of which some are very simple transformations!!!

Additional input could be σpc2\sigma^2_{p_c}. For sure we don’t get estimates of σpc2=σpc,q2+σpc,w2+2σpc,q,pc,w\sigma^2_{p_c} = \sigma^2_{p_{c,q}} + \sigma^2_{p_{c,w}} + 2\sigma_{p_{c,q},p_{c,w}}, but, having sorted the genetic part and if B2pB2_p and B3pB3_p depend only on genetic covariance, then maybe, we have some maneuvering space to estimate also σpq2\sigma^2_{p_q}, σpw2\sigma^2_{p_w}, and σpq,pw2\sigma^2_{{p_q},{p_w}}?!

Furthermore, we have some constraints, so this is not just any system of equations. For example, we know that variances must be positive. Futhermore, we might know that come covariances are either positive or negative.

TODO: Develop and polish all this further and create a Shiny application where we can change these individual-level parameters and study how that will change colony-level parameters and then how we could go the other way around based on literature and solving the above systems of equations. We could host such a Shiny app on SIMplyBee.info!? Can we?
